comments.commentBody: As an entrepreneur, I love reading how an incredible leader like Bloomberg still has fire in his belly at 72.  I hope he's like Buffett and never slows down.
Flights used to be far more expensive, especially when inflation is factored in. We are getting what we pay for, primitive, basic transportation for a cheap price.

"... a gun for more humane euthanasia?" When I was 7 y old and my mother deemed it appropriate for me to learn more about our food supply, I went on a tour (with her) of one of Chicago's then-great meat-packing houses (aka "slaughter houses"). I am uncertain that this is the procedure now followed, though it may be so. Guns in a slaughter house would be an incredible danger and are not less cruel or humane than clubbing.
Here is what I saw: hogs were first clubbed and almost simultaneously their hind legs were grabbed with a hook that was attached to a chain (it was very fast); with their bodies hanging from this chain they were swung carefully so as to be dragged over a large (perhaps 8 or so feet diameter) electrified disk that would basically deliver a fatal or perhaps near-fatal electric shock to them. Alas, I forget whether that step was to ensure they were subdued or to ensure they were dead. Next, their throats were gorged with a large knife to drain their blood. Then (to the best of my recollection) the butchering process began.
The clubbing, hanging, and gorging are ancient slaughter techniques. The electrified disk was a then-modern addition to make all this a bit more humane. I found the entire experience horrifying. It has stuck with me a long time.
I am not sure I buy all these ideas of humaneness (humanity?); but I do believe that skilled clubbing is definitely better, swifter, more effective than a gun.

Congress doesn't care about Knee Defenders or airlines packed like sardines because they're beholden to the 1%.

And the 1% definitely doesn't fly coach, so that makes terrible conditions in the back of commercial airliners a non-issue for our lovely politicians.

Here in Tennessee, I will vote for Lamar Alexander.  He's a good man.  However, I will probably not vote for anyone to represent me in the House, as the Republican candidate is a man of questionable values, and his Democratic opponent is a flake.

When is the average American voter going to realize that he should not vote for those candidates who are popular, but for those candidates and that party whose policies and ideas are best for the average American and for our country?

Well, that is an idea.

One that will not happen. The current POTUS has no power "to sharply limit the amount of outsourcing to Mexico and East Asia. This would bring back millions of well-paying jobs with good benefits, and boost government revenues."

Dream on, baby.

There is no solution here.

Other than Revolution.

But heck, there is no consesus about what to revolt about. Everyone needs to be on the same page for a Revolution, but... there is no page, just rants on TV and divisiveness everywhere.

There was an 'Occupy ' movement back when your country was first formed. But the latest one was dissed, dissmissed, gassed, clubbed, arrested, and guess who won? The equivalet of King George III.

The nominal King George got his comeuppance, but it was just a blink of an eye before the pretenders to the Throne seized it.

The majority of those who voted, living now, voted for this, I wonder if those voters would know who 'King George III' was and be able to identify the time period, and the real issue, which is 'who gets the money'?

These are the just desserts. The downfall after only a few short centuries.

Obama needs to keep himself out there.  His favorite thing is to let the opposition boil the kettle over, without him pouring any cold water on it.  For example, he let the country stew in the birther thing for 6 years, when he should have cooled that off immediately.  And why, not let the country know about the stupid stuff Republicans do, are doing, and will do.
You might want to read the op ed piece in today's Times about the party of Lincoln and how the Republican party's policies have done so much good for this country.

Perhaps my late mum, may she rest in peace, had the best take on this sort of situation. She'd look at the typical choice, and make her pronouncement: "Verfuelte Fisch und verstinkene Herring." ('Verfuelte' means 'rotten', and the rest really needs no translation.) But, thanks to our increasingly expensive and elaborate forms of air pollution known as modern media campaigns, one has to admit that we usually do get the best candidates that money can buy. For what THAT'S worth - and to the typical voter it's often, as those who love math like to say, less than x for any x greater than zero.
And the person behind you should have his or her knees bruised for your sake, why?

I have endured several trans-Atlantic and Pacific flights, including one Delta flight from Atlanta to Paris while seated in the window seat next to a 400 plus pound German man. I learned for the first time that the flight attendant can bring a four foot extension for the seat belt.

Thank goodness I took a sleeping pill shortly after takeoff. I should be able to recline and sleep in peace, especially when an enormously large man is invading my space.
How about actually considering the impact on the lives of the men and women (and of their families) he sends to these conflict zones? Something our former administration never seemed to do.
Since 1895 the LIRR time from Penn to Stony Brook has indeed improved - by 14 minutes (2 hr 4 min in 1895 and now 1 hr 50 minute). But in 1895 one could then continue, all the way to Wading River.
My suggestion: rows A-D recline I-L don't and the people in the middle are undecided.

Do the ticket with a recliner prerogative at $50 extra and acceptance of the offending prerogative at $50 less and mix and match the passenger list to accommodate all. The airline maybe sees the same price, except on flights for skinflints.

In the meantime, LIRR trains out to Port Jeff average as little as 30 MPH during evening rush hour.  Funny thing, in the late 1890's, LIRR trains ran faster than they do to day, while pulled by steam engines!
Bush's fault still? Wrong, Obama owns this mess. Nonexistent leadership and words and acts of weakness.
Obama's leadership has focused on diplomacy and is rather pragmatic. Bush's leadership was utterly destructive. I suppose you prefer destruction to pragmatism and diplomacy.

The foreign policy mistakes of the Bush43 administration have come home to roost. Few if any presidents have been tested more of foreign policy more than this president who is doubly burdened by politics at home. No matter how decisive and committed to the protection of our national interests his decisions are too weak, no matter how strong, too slow no matter how fast he has responded, no matter what he does, he is wrong, incompetent. When I was young people spoke about a “fifth column” referring to an enemy within your own borders.

It is clear that the right wing is itching for war. The beheading of American journalist has caused hysterical and blood thirsty demands for war and going it alone if need be as intended.

Congress will enact authorization for the president to take wide ranging and highly expensive military action. What Congress will not do is to authorize and raise funds to pay for this expensive war. Will Congress enact a war tax or surcharge? Will it be attack not and worry about the cost later?

If we do not get the funding straight we will pay for the war and the excess profits that will result by draconian cuts to Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, Obamacare, public education, food stamps, and every other target in a Ryan budget in steroids. The war will not be paid for by the plutocrats. War is the best way to achieve the corporatist goals of the GOP, which is why the refusal to back the president’s sane policies and are doing their war dance.
Christie blocked the plan to build a train line to Macy's basement.  Then he did nothing to revive the plan to build a new tunnel with 2 tracks to Penn instead.

Are we talking about the LI Snail / Fail / H-ll Road, etc.?  The railroad that still uses the same schedules it had in the 1890's - except a bit slower?  That makes such a high percentage of riders change trains at least once each way?  That runs its only direct Penn to PJ evening trains at 4:19 and 4:49 - before most people leave work?
High bypass capacity over Jamaica station was a huge part of this, but the rebuild of that horror show eliminated that possibility.
Christie stopping ARC's train to Macy's basement made sense - however, he then dropped the ball, when he could have helped push forward new tunnel capacity from Penn NYC into NJ.
The time for other nations to restart their Defense Departments was years ago.  I hope I'm wrong but I think its too late for most.

another factor here may be that dogs were introduced far later into the Kalahari ; they did not serve the role that dogs did in many other cultures as a legitimate companion in hunting and guardianship, and even warmth and hard labor (in the arctic, at least, and perhaps from the last ice age). The Eurasian cultural affinity for dogs has a very long history built on a mutually beneficial working relationship.

in some lands, killing a man's dog was punishable by death.

as well, Eurasian cultures understood the role man had in the dog's creation, and may have felt this responsibility warranted extra care for them.
Always the Progressive Liberal's solution to the problems they create - more tax and spend. It will only end when they finally run out of other people's money.

I rest my case.  Less than an hour, and someone wants to solve this problem (three armed and arguably dangerous (but built on unsound foundations) entities (two of them members of the UN) without spending any money. Freedom is free, is it?
President Obama should ask the Congress for an X% one-time income tax surcharge to fund defense of Y.  Then we'll see where the chicken-hawks stand.

"I see no reason for any American to die in a war is not ours".... They beheaded two American citizens, how many do they have to kill for US to decide to intervine? Two Americans and 1,700 others... whose lives should be considered equally sacred and important.. I know they don´t have oil like Hussein´s Irak, but this is about a bunch of fanatics killing American citizens as well as any other human being who they feel like...  Bush went to war with Irak and Afganistan because some Egiptians decided to attack US on Sept. 11. There was not one terrorist from Irak or Afganistan in those planes.... Now these psychos are beheading Americans in front of a camera and doing mass killings... well, hello, you tell me if that is not a strong reason for US to start doing something...

"I feel terrible for those people, especially for their kids."

Kids themselves have been slaughtered in this region very often.

Sad thing Anca, this mess was of our own creating. If we had never invaded Iraq as awful as Saddam HUssein was, he was contained with the no fly zones and such. Now, the lid is off the pressure cooker and we see the savagery of these thugs.

I feel terrible for those people, especially for their kids. This story is heartbreaking. In the same time though, everyone there expects the US to do something, but none of them does something to stop this genocide. It's nice that there are some Sunni with a big heart helping people like Ali escape - by the way, I don't understand why you revealed their names in the article, won't that expose them to ISIS's retaliation? - but I don't see the Sunni officials and the rich Sunni countries doing something against terrorism. Saudi Arabia, for instance, which has the money to send hundreds of thousands of students here to study, has made an appeal the other day for the US to help stop these monsters, but I don't see them funding an army to help in the process. I don't think any we should send troops there, I see no reason for any American to die in a war that is not ours. The rich countries in the region need to put an end to ISIS themselves - it would be a huge step towards XXIth century civilization that some of them have yet to take.
We made no such promise. We did not give our word to defend Ukraine. That's a lie, told by those who want now to make a new commitment to defend Ukraine, and have us wade into that war.
